subject: Re: [Digest] Dialects
msgSnippet: In my dialect, I would describe hock and hawk as similar to shock and awe - in ock the jaw tends to drop down and the tongue is raised in back while
messageBody:
In my dialect, I would describe "hock" and "hawk" as similar to "shock" and "awe" -
in "ock" the jaw tends to drop down and the tongue is raised in back while the tip touches the bottom of the lower front teeth - the lips tend to be opened in a circle and pulled back exposing the tips of the teeth almost or very slightly;
in "awk" the jaw drops but moves forward slightly while the tongue moves further back in the throat with the tip pushed down to the soft tissue in front of the base of the tongue & at the bottom of the jaw - the lips are still in a circle but smaller & more pushed forward almost like a very slight "oo" shape.
Just the way it sounds & feels to me.

On 7. Jan, 2007, at 5:42, Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com wrote:

Re: Dialects

Posted by: "tim_rice09" tim_rice09@...   tim_rice09

Sat Jan 6, 2007 12:55 pm (PST)

Well, the vowels for hawk and hock in my and many others speech are
one and the same. Though I still write them differently in
Quickscript. ...

In my dialect, I would describe "hock" and "hawk" as similar to  
"shock" and "awe" -
in "ock" the jaw tends to drop down and the tongue is raised in back  
while the tip touches the bottom of the lower front teeth - the lips  
tend to be opened in a circle and pulled back exposing the tips of  
the teeth almost or very slightly;
in "awk" the jaw drops but moves forward slightly while the tongue  
moves further back in the throat with the tip pushed down to the soft  
tissue in front of the base of the tongue & at the bottom of the jaw  
- the lips are still in a circle but smaller & more pushed forward  
almost like a very slight "oo" shape.
Just the way it sounds & feels to me.

Re: Dialects

Posted by: "tim_rice09" tim_rice09@...   tim_rice09

Sat Jan 6, 2007 12:55 pm (PST)

Well, the vowels for hawk and hock in my and many others speech are
one and the same. Though I still write them differently in
Quickscript. ...
